s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: This course provides basic approaches for designing and analysing algorithms and data structures.

s1: The lectures will also address recent literature describing advances in operating systems.
s2: This course provides basic approaches for designing and analysing algorithms and data structures.

s1: The following topics are addressed: system programming and its facilities (including I/O, signals, job control, interprocess communication, sockets, transport layers, remote operations), system calls and their relation to the system libraries, process management and coordination, implementation of message passing, memory management, interrupt handling, real-time clocks, device-independent input/output, serial-line drivers, network communication, disk drivers, deadlock avoidance, scheduling paradigms, file systems, security.
s2: Display an advanced understanding of a variety of algorithms, including linear selection, minimum spanning trees, single source shortest path, Huffman coding, etc, with real-life applications and the resource requirements.

s1: identify and evaluate features of the system library of a particular operating system, and be able to apply this knowledge to program small applications.
s2: Demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of algorithms for practical problems, using languages like C, C++.

s1: describe and analyse the actual algorithms and data structures that are used in a particular operating system.
s2: This course provides basic approaches for designing and analysing algorithms and data structures.

s1: define and analyse the structure of operating systems in general, especially those that support communicating processes.
s2: This course provides basic approaches for designing and analysing algorithms and data structures.

s1: identify and describe the reasons for many architectural features of contemporary machines.
s2: Define and analyse time and space complexities of algorithms.

s1: demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of a large software system.
s2: Demonstrate experience in the design and implementation of algorithms for practical problems, using languages like C, C++.
